title: LA Art Show 2026
description: Latin American Pavilion curated by Marisa Caichiolo explores memory, migration, and identity. DIVERSEartLA section focuses on ecological and social justice themes.

title: Oshogatsu Family Festival - Year of the Horse
description: JANM celebrates the New Year with cultural activities while galleries undergo renovation. Part of JANM on the Go program.
mapQuery: Japanese American Cultural Community Center Little Tokyo Los Angeles

title: Act On It! Artists, Community, and the Brockman Gallery
description: Exhibition highlighting Black artists and community activism in Los Angeles art history.
mapQuery: Vincent Price Art Museum East LA College Monterey Park

title: Indigenous Youth Migration Project
description: Multi-disciplinary exhibition focused on Indigenous youth from southern Mexico and Central America separated from families at the US-Mexico border. Created with artist Oscar Magallanes.
mapQuery: Museum of Social Justice 115 Paseo de la Plaza Los Angeles

title: Radical Histories: Chicano Prints from the Smithsonian
description: 60 works by 40+ Chicano artists exploring UFW labor movement, farmworkers' rights, and community activism. Includes new commissioned mural by Melissa Govea.

title: The Great Wall of Los Angeles (LA Phil Concert)
description: Gustavo Dudamel and Gabriela Ortiz bring together composers to create an hour-long symphonic tribute to Angelenos who shaped LA's history, inspired by Judy Baca's mural. Features original film by Alejandro G. Iñárritu.
mapQuery: Walt Disney Concert Hall Los Angeles

title: LA Climate Week 2026
description: Community-led movement with 75+ diverse events focused on climate action, culture, and equity. Art builds, film screenings, forums, street festivals, and cultural programming across LA.

title: Independent Bookstore Day
description: Citywide celebration at LA's independent bookstores including All Power Books, Strategy and Soul, Reparations Club, and others. Many host activism-focused events and readings.

title: Harvey Milk Day Celebration & WeHo Pride Kickoff
description: Official kickoff of WeHo Pride 2026 celebrating Harvey Milk Day. Features José Sarria Drag Pageant and begins 40 days of LGBTQ+ arts, culture, and community programming across West Hollywood.

title: WeHo Pride Arts Festival 2026
venue: LA LGBT Center - Village at Ed Gould Plaza
description: Annual celebration of LGBTQ+ creativity featuring theatre, cabaret, music, literary readings, dance, film presentations, and art-making workshops. Showcases artists and storytellers who amplify LGBTQ+ voices and experiences. All events free to attend.
mapQuery: LA LGBT Center Village Ed Gould Plaza 1125 N McCadden Place Los Angeles

title: Yoko Ono: Music of the Mind
description: First-ever solo museum exhibition by the artist and activist in Southern California. Features anti-war works Acorn Event (1968) and Bed Peace (1969) created with John Lennon. Interactive participatory works.

title: WeHo Pride Weekend 2026
description: Major Pride weekend featuring OUTLOUD Music Festival (Kylie Minogue, Janelle Monāe, Diplo headlining), WeHo Pride Street Fair, Women's Freedom Festival, Dyke March, and WeHo Pride Parade. One of the largest LGBTQ+ celebrations in the world.

title: MOLAA Summer Camp: Artivism Week
venue: Museum of Latin American Art (MOLAA), Long Beach
description: Youth summer camp week focused on art and activism for change. Bilingual program for young artists combining artmaking with social justice themes.
mapQuery: MOLAA Museum Latin American Art 628 Alamitos Long Beach

title: A Great Day in East L.A.: Celebrando the Eastside Sound
venue: LA Plaza de Cultura y Artes
description: Multi-media exhibition exploring dynamic musical influences of East LA artists with portraits and oral histories. Over 500 albums, instruments, and ephemera celebrating Eastside sound and cultural identity.
mapQuery: LA Plaza de Cultura y Artes 501 N Main St Los Angeles

title: Every Minute Is History: Five Views of Los Angeles
description: Five photographers (Laura Aguilar, Reynaldo Rivera, George Rodriguez, Patssi Valdez, Ricardo Valverde) who expanded Chicano and Chicana representation in Los Angeles through innovative techniques.

title: Confederate Statues & Contemporary Responses
description: Decommissioned Confederate statues paired with contemporary work by Kara Walker, Hank Willis Thomas, and others. Addresses white supremacy and historical reckoning.

title: Native Skate
description: Traces skateboarding's Southern California origins and the importance of the sport in Indigenous communities, especially among Native youth.

title: One of Us: Portraits and Personal Stories
description: David Blumenkrantz's photography project exploring homelessness in Los Angeles.
mapQuery: Museum of Social Justice 115 Paseo de la Plaza Los Angeles

title: Immigrant Communities Projection Project
venue: LA Plaza de Cultura y Artes
description: Large-scale exterior wall projections exploring ongoing realities faced by immigrant and undocumented communities in Los Angeles. Collaborative project with 4 partner organizations.
mapQuery: LA Plaza de Cultura y Artes 501 N Main St Los Angeles

title: LA Starts Here! (Permanent Exhibition)
venue: LA Plaza de Cultura y Artes
description: Alternative interpretation of LA history from Mexican and Mexican American perspectives. Groundbreaking permanent exhibition addressing marginalized narratives.
mapQuery: LA Plaza de Cultura y Artes 501 N Main St Los Angeles

title: The Great Wall of Los Angeles (Permanent Monument)
venue: Tujunga Flood Control Channel, North Hollywood
description: One of the longest murals in the world depicting California history from prehistoric times to present. Created by Judy Baca and SPARC. Currently being expanded to cover 1960s-2000s. New interpretive bridge viewing station.
mapQuery: Great Wall of Los Angeles Coldwater Canyon North Hollywood

title: The 1960s: A Generation on Fire (Great Wall Extension)
description: Latest extension of the Great Wall of Los Angeles featuring 1960s activism. Work in progress by Judy Baca showcasing the energy of movement builders from that pivotal decade.
mapQuery: SPARC Bergamot Station 2525 Michigan Ave Santa Monica

title: SPARC Día de los Muertos Celebration
description: 23rd annual Día de los Muertos celebration and ritual featuring altars, art, food, mariachis, and gallery remarks. Community celebration honoring the departed.
mapQuery: SPARC Bergamot Station 2525 Michigan Ave Santa Monica

title: All Power Books Community Programs
description: Marxist cooperative bookstore hosting documentary screenings, writing workshops, poetry readings, and mutual aid. Community hub for advocacy work with LA Tenants Union, Street Watch LA, and Say Their Name LA.
mapQuery: All Power Books West Adams Los Angeles

title: Strategy and Soul Bookstore Events
venue: Strategy and Soul Bookstore, South Central LA
description: Afrocentric bookstore focusing on Third World revolutionary movements, Black liberation, and anti-imperialist organizing. Part of The Labor Community Strategy Center. Ongoing talks and readings.
mapQuery: Strategy and Soul Bookstore South Central Los Angeles

title: LA Libros Festival 2026
description: Full day of Spanish-language and bilingual storytelling, musical performances, authors, workshops, books, and community celebration. Free and open to the public.
mapQuery: Central Library 630 W 5th St Los Angeles

title: Art + Activism Summer Program
description: Multi-generational mentorship program bringing together high school students and UCLA mentors to explore intersections of art and activism. Paid internships for youth. Portfolio-building and professional skills development.

title: Del Alma: Latina Portraits
description: Intergenerational group of portraits by LA-based Latina artists exploring cultural identity and diverse creative expression.
mapQuery: Vincent Price Art Museum East LA College Monterey Park

title: sister dreamer: lauren halsey's architectural ode
description: Sculpture park and monument to South Central LA by artist Lauren Halsey. Space for community gatherings including film screenings, musical performances, and lectures. Employs ancient Egyptian iconography to reclaim lost legacies.

title: Ofelia Esparza: A Retrospective
description: Retrospective of artist Ofelia Esparza's work exploring Día de la Virgen de Guadalupe traditions, family artifacts, and cultural memory passed down through generations.
mapQuery: Vincent Price Art Museum East LA College Monterey Park

title: ONE Gallery: LGBTQ+ Exhibitions
description: Rotating exhibitions on LGBTQ+ art and history. City-owned space presenting temporary exhibitions highlighting queer artists and histories. Part of ONE National Gay & Lesbian Archives initiative.

title: ONE Archives at USC: Research & Programs
description: Largest repository of LGBTQ+ materials in the world. Over 2 million items documenting LGBTQ+ history since 1952. Hosts exhibitions, talks, and educational programs. Free public access to collections.
mapQuery: ONE Archives USC 909 West Adams Boulevard Los Angeles

title: LA LGBT Center: Arts & Events Programming
venue: LA LGBT Center - Village at Ed Gould Plaza
description: Year-round cultural programming including theatre, film screenings, panels, concerts, and community events. Home to Davidson/Valentini Theatre. Ongoing LGBTQ+ arts and activism events.
mapQuery: LA LGBT Center Village Ed Gould Plaza 1125 N McCadden Place Los Angeles

title: Circa: Queer Histories Festival 2026
description: First and only queer histories festival in the US. Month-long LA County-wide programming showcasing trailblazing LGBTQ+ histories and cultural contributions through exhibitions, performances, screenings, lectures, and community celebrations.

title: Hospital of Emotions - Call for Artists
description: 100 artists transform hospital rooms into site-specific installations exploring human emotions. Artist fee: $4,000 per room + materials budget. On-site installation mid-April 2026, exhibition opens mid-May 2026. All disciplines welcome.

title: LA City COLA Individual Master Artist Project
description: Recognition and funding for accomplished LA-based literary, performing, and visual artists. Application cycle runs each autumn.

title: LA City Neighborhood Engagement Artist Residencies (NEAR)
description: Artists-in-residence partnerships within LA communities. Fee: $6,000 or $12,000. Community-based participatory projects: 11+ sessions with public presentation. Teaching artists, social-activation artists, social practice artists.

title: LA City Creative Optimism-Uplifting Promises (CO-UP)
description: Collaborations between social-justice nonprofits and artists. Fee: $15,000 ($12k artist, $3k org). Social justice nonprofits with $100k+ budget partner with artists for 11-session residencies with public presentation.

title: LACE Lightning Fund Artist Grants
description: Grants for visual artists practicing in LA County. Expansive definition includes film/video, new media, sound art, performance art, social practice. Decisions by January 2026.

title: LA County Community Impact Arts Grant (CIAG)
description: Fee: $1,200-$7,100. Arts projects at social service/social justice nonprofits, municipal departments, tribal governments. Cross-sector civic problem solving through arts and culture.

title: West Hollywood WeHo Artist Grant
description: Up to $30,000 total funding available. For artists with history supporting LGBTQ, BIPOC, and/or female artists. Supports long-term artist development to keep artists in WeHo.

title: West Hollywood TGI+ Arts Grant
description: Up to $30,000 total funding available. For artists, collectives, nonprofits with commitment to transgender, non-binary, intersex, gender non-conforming community. Projects may take place in June but separate from WeHo Pride.

title: Doan Foundation Roots & Resilience Artist Grant
description: Fee: $1,000 (six artists funded). For artists exploring cultural heritage, community strength, resilience, social issues, mental health, uplifting underrepresented voices.

title: Walker Youngbird Foundation Emerging Native Arts Grant
description: Fee: $15,000. For early-career Native artists honoring tradition while shaping future of contemporary Indigenous art. Includes mentorship and curated showcase. Awarded twice annually.

title: First Peoples Fund Yéego Action Grant
description: Fee: Up to $2,500. Rolling monthly grants for Native artists/culture bearers needing quick financial assistance for professional opportunities or hardships. 'Yéego' means 'keep going, don't give up' in Diné.

title: First Peoples Fund Native Performing Arts Fellowship
description: Fee: Up to $10,000. For Native performing artists (theater, dance, music, spoken word). Includes professional development curriculum, industry guidance, annual multi-day fellowship gathering. Must provide tribal enrollment documentation.

title: NDN Collective Radical Imagination Grant
description: Fee: $50,000 (six artists funded). For Indigenous artists/culture bearers of all traditions, mediums, genres. Major support for radical artistic vision.

title: Creative Capital Award
description: Fee: $15,000-$50,000. Unrestricted project grants for new artistic works in visual arts, performing arts, film, and literature. State of the Art Prize: $10,000 unrestricted grants.

title: Syracuse Cultural Workers Women Artists Datebook
description: Fee: $200 (cover) / $70 (inside art) + datebooks. Art that instigates activism, challenges power. For all women and femmes (LGBTQIAA+). Seeks inspirational work promoting activism and/or healing. No submission fee.

title: Making A Difference (M.A.D.) Exhibition
description: National juried exhibition: art as catalyst for change. Theme: self-care, justice advocacy, environmental protection, fostering connection. All mediums. Proceeds support artists and future exhibitions.

title: Climate Creative Awards 'Collective Power'
description: Theme: Collective Power - unity, solidarity, shared vision for climate transformation. Month-long exhibitions, performances, film festival in NYC. 2D/3D works, films, performances. Celebrate collaboration, amplify frontline voices.

title: John O. Calmore Creative Activism Artist Residency
description: Fee: $6,000 stipend + exhibition + lodging + studio. Application fee: $35. For citizen artists in visual arts, film, video, new media, interdisciplinary practices dedicated to social justice. Exhibition in Toronto included.
